instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3588: What is 820-3588? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3588</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (imac) - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message:
iMac 21" 2013

no power.
no lights on MLB
Tried known good PSU same result.

Found that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> has a dead short to ground.
Seems to be on pin 1 of L7610 (0v diode mode)
Pin 2 of L7610 is 0.125v

Tried injecting some voltage got to 3amp @ 0.7volts

Not done many iMac boards so am unsure as to how much current i can put in this rail, or if there are any common issues on these
Thanks again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3588</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (imac) - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message: You can inject 3V, but it is better to monitor current and once 1-2 watts are going in something should heat up. You had 3x0.7=2.1W flowing into the board so there should something be heating up. Could be any cap on that line really. Worst case would be the PCH/CPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3588</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (imac) - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message: Thanks Duke, it is <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> that is getting hot unfortunately. One for the parts pin. Thanks for confirming.
